title: Leave voters go head-to-head with anti-Brexit protesters
text:
Brexit tension threatened to boil over today as Remain activists on the People's Vote march clashed with a Leave counter-protest.

Heated exchanges between campaigners from either side of the political divide broke out in Parliament Square where tens of thousands of pro-EU activists had gathered to demand a second referendum.

The flare-up prompted a Metropolitan Police officer to move between the two groups who were pictured having an animated confrontation.

Super Saturday's crunch vote on Boris Johnson's Brexit deal has stoked strong emotions in both grassroots Remainers and Leavers who are trying to persuade MPs to swing behind their preferred outcome.

The division in the Commons - which is sitting on a weekend for the first time since 1982 - spilled over on to the streets this afternoon.

A woman from the Remain rally was seen squaring up to a pro-Brexit campaigner draped in a Union Flag.

This Eurosceptic was accompanied by female fellow Leaver who also appeared to argue with the Remainer.

A scrum of people immediately encircled the quarreling pair and started filming them.

Elsewhere, two men on opposing sides were pictured clashing as the counter-protest moved on to the People's Vote rally turf on Parliament Square Gardens.

Again, a police officer was seen nearby, poised to step in the event of escalating tension.

A woman from the Remain rally was seen squaring up to two pro-Brexit campaigners draped in a Union Flag

The Brexiteers counter-protest was dwarfed by the tens of thousands of People's Vote campaigners

The Brexiteers counter-protest was dwarfed by the tens of thousands of People's Vote campaigners, who counted celebrities, politicians and even Mr Broccoli among their ranks.

He will be joined by shadow chancellor John McDonnell - a late convert to back a second referendum - who will address the crowds outside Parliament this afternoon.

As of Saturday morning, more than £500,000 has been donated to support the protest, and cross-party politicians are calling on people to get involved.

More than 170 coaches from around Britain were due to arrive in London today taking people to the march.
